prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: 230GHz at SMA gives a integrated flux of 60mJy with approximate target size of 0.76 x 0.73 arcsec. (Beam size is 1.0x1.7 arcsec). If this target is observed 0.12 x 0.12 arcsec and beta=1 to convert 345GHz, approximately peak intensity will be 2.33 mJy/beam.

230GHz at SMA gives a integrated flux of 49mJy with approximate target size of 0.74 x 0.44 arcsec. (Beam size is 1.0x1.7 arcsec). If this target is observed 0.12 x 0.12 arcsec, and beta=1 to convert 345GHz approximately peak intensity will be 2.17 mJy/beam. If S/N=40 at peak is requested, 40 min is required, but hoping match same noise level as RXJ1852.3, we request 56 min (S/N=65).

230GHz at SMA gives a integrated flux of 60mJy with approximate target size of 0.76 x 0.73 arcsec. (Beam size is 1.0x1.7 arcsec). If this target is observed 0.18 x 0.18 arcsec, approximately peak intensity will be 3.5 mJy/beam. If S/N=100 is requested for beta, it will request 45 minutes.

230GHz at SMA gives a integrated flux of 49mJy with approximate target size of 0.74 x 0.44 arcsec. (Beam size is 1.0x1.7 arcsec). If this target is observed 0.18 x 0.18 arcsec, approximately peak intensity will be 4.87 mJy/beam. If S/N=100 at peak is requested, 36 minutes is required.
The peak intensities are estimated from SMA 230GHz data. Signal to noise ratio might be not enough, but to cover wider wavelength range, we request this frequency.
Peak intensity is estimated from 230GHz SMA observations. Although spatial resolution is not enough, we need this wavelength to cover the larger dust grains.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We propose observation of two classical T Tauri stars just before ceases accretion, to understand how dust grain evolves in the circumstellar disk. Two targets, RX J1842.9-3532 and RX J1852.3-3700 located 130 pc from our sun, are early-K type classical T Tauri stars with dust disks. From our recent observations, circumstellar disk of RX J1852.3-3700 was resolved into gap-like structure and asymmetric outer ring. Because our near-infrared scattered light image does not trace the real column density distribution, we propose to measure sub-mm continuum to reveal 1) spatial distribution of dust, and 2) its opacity changing by grain growth of dust.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Circumstellar disks, exoplanets and the solar system

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: Division of Optical and Infrared Astronomy, National Astronomical Observatory of Japan
